prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 7 continuum mapping of COSMOS SMGs (First 32)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: First group of 32 SMGs randomly selected from sample.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The ALMA Cycle 0 Band 7 study of bright 870-um sources (detected at >3.7-sigma with LABOCA in ECDFS, where sigma=1.2 mJy) by Hodge et al. (2013) identified - for the first time - the intense starbursts powering a sample of ~100 of these prodigious systems without relying on statistical associations of the submillimetre flux with counterparts in other wavebands. Hodge et al. showed that the previous radio/mid-IR associations pinpoint the correct submm-luminous counterpart in only ~55% of cases, meaning that nearly half of the submm sources were either not identified or misidentified by the statistical associations. Given the importance of properly characterising the SMG population for constraining models of galaxy formation, we propose to more than double the sample of precisely-located SMGs through a programme of ALMA Band 7 870-um observations of bright submillimetre sources drawn from the new SCUBA-2 Cosmology Legacy Survey maps of the COSMOS field.
The SCUBA-2 CLS survey is on-going, however we have already reached our target sensitivity of 1.2 mJy at 870um for a 0.5-square degrees region in COSMOS, which is therefore complete. In this area we detect 128 sources at >3.75 sigma significance. At this level we expect 0.4 spurious SCUBA-2 sources, implying that our proposed ALMA follow-up should not be afflicted by many false detections. We therefore propose to observe the complete sample of submm sources in COSMOS to exploit the exceptional multiwavelength archival data available on degree-scales in this field.
With the increase in the number of available antennas since the Cycle 0 ALESS programme, we aim to improve on the depth and quality of the maps used in ALESS (for which their "GOOD" sample had a typical rms 0.38+/-0.05 mJy, with only 30% of their maps better than this). We therefore adopt for a limit of 0.17mJy/beam meaning that the faintest sources in our sample, if they correspond to a single SMG, will be detected at >25-sigma. However, as Hodge et al. demonstrated, there is significant evidence for blending in submm source catalogues, meaning that we expect many of our targets to contain several SMGs, 2-4 at the sensitivity limit of ALESS. Our requested depth will allow us to detect sub-components with fluxes brighter than 15% of the total flux of the submm source in even our faintest targets. This will allow a more complete survey for faint SMGs components in these regions to determine the variation in multiplicity as a function of apparent single-dish source flux, which is critical for understanding the influence of blending on SMG number counts. The ALMA OT sensitivity calculator indicates that we will be able to map all 128 of our bright COSMOS SMGs to this limit in 6.36h, including all overheads. In order to make our observations more easily schedulable, and to ensure that partial completeness does not bias our study, we have randomly split our targets in to four groups within the OT.
As the key objective of our proposal is to detect the counterpart(s) to SCUBA-2 sources, we request the most compact C34-1 configuration; the 1" synthesized beam in Band 7 is ideal for detecting sources at z>1 which are extended on <1" or <8kpc scales (their likely extents, Engels et al. 2010), while the maximum recoverable scale will allow for detection of any extended emission upto 7.6" (~60kpc). We select the standard TDM correlator setup for continuum observations, with 4x128 dual-polarisation channels over a 7.50GHz bandwidth centred on 344GHz. Based on experience from ALESS, we would expect ~3-4 serendipitous detections of z~4-4.5 [CII]157um emitters in our cubes (Swinbank et al. 2012) to improve the constraints on the [CII] luminosity function at high-z, but the line-widths of these sources should still be resolved even in TDM.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
Single-dish submm surveys have yielded samples of thousands of extragalactic (z>1) sources, hosting prodigious, dust-enshrouded star formation (SFR > 100-1000 Mo/yr). The z-distribution of submm galaxies (SMGs) peaks at z~2-3, the epoch at which the universal SFR density peaks, where they are ~1000x more prevalent than ultra-luminous analogues are at z~0. SMGs have been linked to the formation of QSOs and local ellipticals, but prior to ALMA identification of SMG counterparts at other wavelengths was limited to the subset of sources that were unusually bright in those bands.
We propose Band 7 continuum observations of 128 SMGs identified in a SCUBA-2 survey of the COSMOS field. These observations will pinpoint the individual SMGs within these sources, allowing us to identify counterparts in the pan-chromatic coverage of COSMOS without recourse to statistical associations. From these observations, we will measure the source counts and multiplicity, identify the most distant/coolest SMGs (to which radio/mid-IR studies are insensitive), and provide the first reliable measurements of the one-halo term of the angular correlation function for bright, star-forming SMGs at z>1.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:relatedProposals: More than LESS: The first fully-identified submillimetre survey (2011.0.00294.S) The bright end of the submm counts: real or not? (2012.1.00090.S)
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
